accuracy.explanation:
The proportion of correct predictions among the total number of cases processed.
The ideal value is 1.0.
accuracy.citation:
@article{scikit-learn,
    title={Scikit-learn: Machine Learning in {P}ython},
    author={Pedregosa, F. and Varoquaux, G. and Gramfort, A. and Michel, V.
    and Thirion, B. and Grisel, O. and Blondel, M. and Prettenhofer, P.
    and Weiss, R. and Dubourg, V. and Vanderplas, J. and Passos, A. and
    Cournapeau, D. and Brucher, M. and Perrot, M. and Duchesnay, E.},
    journal={Journal of Machine Learning Research},
    volume={12},
    pages={2825--2830},
    year={2011}
}

balanced_accuracy.explanation:
Describes the proportion of correct predictions averaged across each label.
The ideal value is 1.0.

confusion_matrix.explanation: A Confusion Matrix C is a matrix C such that C(i,j) is equal to the number of observations known to be in group i and predicted to be in group j.
confusion_matrix.citation:
@article{scikit-learn,

f1.explanation:
Can be interpreted as a harmonic mean of the precision and recall.
The formula for the F1 score is: F1 = 2 * (precision * recall) / (precision + recall)
The idea value is 1.0 and the worst value is 0.0.
f1.citation:
@article{scikit-learn,
    title={Scikit-learn: Machine Learning in {P}ython},

    year={2011}
}

The ideal value is 0.0.

jaccard_score.explanation:
Measures the similarity of two two sets of data, and returns a result from 0 to 100%.
It is the size of the intersection divided by the size of the union of two label sets.
It is used to compare set of predicted labels for a sample to the corresponding set of labels in y_true.
The ideal score is 1.0.
jaccard_score.citation:
@article{scikit-learn,
    title={Scikit-learn: Machine Learning in {P}ython},
    author={Pedregosa, F. and Varoquaux, G. and Gramfort, A. and Michel, V.

    and Weiss, R. and Dubourg, V. and Vanderplas, J. and Passos, A. and
    Cournapeau, D. and Brucher, M. and Perrot, M. and Duchesnay, E.},

    volume={12},
    pages={2825--2830},
    year={2011}
}

precision_score.explanation:
The percentage of positive predictions that were correct.
Indicates a models ability to not label a positive sample as negative.
Ideal value is 1.0.
precision_score.citation:

recall_score.explanation:
The percentage of positive examples that were correctly labeled as positive.
Indicates a models ability to classify all positive image samples
Ideal value is 1.0.
